evidence.text: Since at least 2015, DFD has used a multi-step selection process to select entry-level firefighters. Among other screening devices, this multi-step selection process has included the use of scores from a written test.

extracted.value: Since at least 2015, DFD has used a multi-step selection process to select entry-level firefighters. Among other screening devices, this multi-step selection process has included the use of scores from a written test.

evidence.text: Approximately 37% of African-American test-takers failed the written test, and approximately 11% of white test-takers failed. During this time period, the difference between the pass rates of African-American and white test-takers on the written test is statistically significant, with a standard deviation of more than three units.

extracted.value: African-American applicants failed the written test at a higher rate than white applicants (37% vs 11% failure rates), with statistically significant disparity (standard deviation >3 units).

evidence.text: Approximately 32% of African-American applicants who were eligible for an interview failed to receive an invitation to interview, and approximately 14% of white applicants who were eligible for an interview failed to receive an invitation. During this time period, the difference between the rates of African-American and white applicants who were invited for in-person interviews is statistically significant, with a standard deviation of more than three units.

extracted.value: African-American applicants who passed the written test were invited for interviews at a lower rate than white applicants (32% vs 14%), with statistically significant disparity (standard deviation >3 units).

evidence.text: The CEB and the methods in which Defendant has used the CEB are not job related and consistent with business necessity. As such, Defendant’s uses of the CEB during (i) the pass/fail testing step of the selection process and (ii) the step of the selection process when Defendant rank-orders applicants for interviews are both not job related for the DFD entry-level firefighter position, not consistent with business necessity, and do not otherwise meet the requirements of Section 703(k) of Title VII.

extracted.value: The CEB and Defendant's use of it are not job-related, consistent with business necessity, or meet Title VII requirements.

evidence.text: As a result of Defendant’s uses of the CEB, Defendant has hired at least sixteen (16) fewer African-American applicants as entry-level firefighters since 2015 than it otherwise would have had it used a non-discriminatory screening device.

extracted.value: Defendant hired at least 16 fewer African-American applicants as entry-level firefighters since 2015 due to the discriminatory screening process.
